metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JavaScript Arrays
An array is a special variable, which can hold more than one value:
content.html: An array is a special variable, which can hold more than one value:

content.code: const cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];
content.code_html: const cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];

content.text: Try it Yourself »
content.html: Try it Yourself »

content.text: Why Use Arrays?
If you have a list of items (a list of car names, for example), storing the cars in single variables could look like this:
content.html: If you have a list of items (a list of car names, for example), storing the cars in single variables could look like this:

content.code_html:
let car1 = "Saab";
let car2 = "Volvo";
let car3 = "BMW";

content.text: However, what if you want to loop through the cars and find a specific one? And what if you had not 3 cars, but 300?
content.html: However, what if you want to loop through the cars and find a specific one? And what if you had not 3 cars, but 300?

content.text: The solution is an array!
content.html: The solution is an array!

content.text: An array can hold many values under a single name, and you can access the values by referring to an index number.
content.html: An array can hold many values under a single name, and you can access the values by referring to an index number.

content.text: Creating an Array
Using an array literal is the easiest way to create a JavaScript Array.
content.html: Using an array literal is the easiest way to create a JavaScript Array.

content.text: Syntax:
content.html: Syntax:

content.code: const array_name = [item1, item2, ...];
content.code_html: const array_name = [item1, item2, ...];

content.text: It is a common practice to declare arrays with the const keyword.
content.html: It is a common practice to declare arrays with the const keyword.

content.text: Learn more about const with arrays in the chapter: JS Array Const .
content.html: Learn more about const with arrays in the chapter: JS Array Const.

content.code: const cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];
content.code_html: const cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];

content.text: Spaces and line breaks are not important. A declaration can span multiple lines:
content.html: Spaces and line breaks are not important. A declaration can span multiple lines:

content.code_html:
const cars = [
  "Saab",
  "Volvo",
  "BMW"
];

content.text: You can also create an array, and then provide the elements:
content.html: You can also create an array, and then provide the elements:

content.code_html:
const cars = [];
cars[0]= "Saab";
cars[1]= "Volvo";
cars[2]= "BMW";

content.text: Using the JavaScript Keyword new
The following example also creates an Array, and assigns values to it:
content.html: The following example also creates an Array, and assigns values to it:

content.code: const cars = new Array("Saab", "Volvo", "BMW");
content.code_html: const cars = new Array("Saab", "Volvo", "BMW");

content.text: The two examples above do exactly the same.
content.html: The two examples above do exactly the same.

content.text: There is no need to use new Array() .
content.html: There is no need to use new Array().

content.text: For simplicity, readability and execution speed, use the array literal method.
content.html: For simplicity, readability and execution speed, use the array literal method.

content.text: Accessing Array Elements
You access an array element by referring to the index number :
content.html: You access an array element by referring to the index number:

content.code:
const cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];
let car = cars[0];
content.code_html:
const cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];
let car = cars[0];

content.text: Note: Array indexes start with 0.
content.html: Note: Array indexes start with 0.

content.text: [0] is the first element. [1] is the second element.
content.html: [0] is the first element. [1] is the second element.

content.text: Changing an Array Element
This statement changes the value of the first element in cars :
content.html: This statement changes the value of the first element in cars:

content.code: cars[0] = "Opel";
content.code_html: cars[0] = "Opel";

content.code:
const cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];
cars[0] = "Opel";
content.code_html:
const cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];
cars[0] = "Opel";

content.text: Converting an Array to a String
The JavaScript method toString() converts an array to a string of (comma separated) array values.
content.html: The JavaScript method toString() converts an array to a string of (comma separated) array values.

content.code:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = fruits.toString();
content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = fruits.toString();

content.text: Access the Full Array
With JavaScript, the full array can be accessed by referring to the array name:
content.html: With JavaScript, the full array can be accessed by referring to the array name:

content.code:
const cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = cars;
content.code_html:
const cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = cars;

content.text: Arrays are Objects
Arrays are a special type of objects. The typeof operator in JavaScript returns "object" for arrays.
content.html: Arrays are a special type of objects. The typeof operator in JavaScript returns "object" for arrays.

content.text: But, JavaScript arrays are best described as arrays.
content.html: But, JavaScript arrays are best described as arrays.

content.text: Arrays use numbers to access its "elements". In this example, person[0] returns John:
content.html: Arrays use numbers to access its "elements". In this example, person[0] returns John:

content.code: const person = ["John", "Doe", 46];
content.code_html: const person = ["John", "Doe", 46];

content.text: Objects use names to access its "members". In this example, person.firstName returns John:
content.html: Objects use names to access its "members". In this example, person.firstName returns John:

content.code: const person = {firstName:"John", lastName:"Doe", age:46};
content.code_html: const person = {firstName:"John", lastName:"Doe", age:46};

content.text: Array Elements Can Be Objects
JavaScript variables can be objects. Arrays are special kinds of objects.
content.html: JavaScript variables can be objects. Arrays are special kinds of objects.

content.text: Because of this, you can have variables of different types in the same Array.
content.html: Because of this, you can have variables of different types in the same Array.

content.text: You can have objects in an Array. You can have functions in an Array. You can have arrays in an Array:
content.html: You can have objects in an Array. You can have functions in an Array. You can have arrays in an Array:

content.code_html:
myArray[0] = Date.now;
myArray[1] = myFunction;
myArray[2] = myCars;

content.text: Array Properties and Methods
The real strength of JavaScript arrays are the built-in array properties and methods:
content.html: The real strength of JavaScript arrays are the built-in array properties and methods:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
cars.length   // Returns the number of elements
cars.sort()   // Sorts the array

content.code:
cars.length   // Returns the number of elements
cars.sort()   // Sorts the array

syntax_highlighting.text:
cars.length   // Returns the number of elements
cars.sort()   // Sorts the array

content.code_html:
cars.length   // Returns the number of elements
 cars.sort()   // Sorts the array

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
cars.length   // Returns the number of elements
cars.sort()   // Sorts the array

content.text: Array methods are covered in the next chapters.
content.html: Array methods are covered in the next chapters.

content.text: The length Property
The length property of an array returns the length of an array (the number of array elements).
content.html: The length property of an array returns the length of an array (the number of array elements).

content.code:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
let length = fruits.length;
content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
let length = fruits.length;

content.text: The length property is always one more than the highest array index.
content.html: The length property is always one more than the highest array index.

content.text: Accessing the First Array Element

content.code:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
let fruit = fruits[0];
content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
let fruit = fruits[0];

content.text: Accessing the Last Array Element

content.code:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
let fruit = fruits[fruits.length - 1];
content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
let fruit = fruits[fruits.length - 1];

content.text: Looping Array Elements
One way to loop through an array, is using a for loop:
content.html: One way to loop through an array, is using a for loop:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
let fLen = fruits.length;

let text = "<ul>";
for (let i = 0; i < fLen; i++) {
  text += "<li>" + fruits[i] + "</li>";
}
text += "</ul>";

content.text: You can also use the Array.forEach() function:
content.html: You can also use the Array.forEach() function:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];

let text = "<ul>";
fruits.forEach(myFunction);
text += "</ul>";

function myFunction(value) {
  text += "<li>" + value + "</li>";
}

content.text: Adding Array Elements
The easiest way to add a new element to an array is using the push() method:
content.html: The easiest way to add a new element to an array is using the push() method:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
fruits.push("Lemon");  // Adds a new element (Lemon) to fruits
// Adds a new element (Lemon) to fruits

content.code:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
fruits.push("Lemon");  // Adds a new element (Lemon) to fruits

syntax_highlighting.text:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
fruits.push("Lemon");  // Adds a new element (Lemon) to fruits
// Adds a new element (Lemon) to fruits

content.code_html:

fruits.push("Lemon");  // Adds a new element (Lemon) to fruits

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
fruits.push("Lemon");  // Adds a new element (Lemon) to fruits
// Adds a new element (Lemon) to fruits

content.text: New element can also be added to an array using the length property:
content.html: New element can also be added to an array using the length property:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
fruits[fruits.length] = "Lemon";  // Adds "Lemon" to fruits

content.code:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
fruits[fruits.length] = "Lemon";  // Adds "Lemon" to fruits

syntax_highlighting.text:

fruits[fruits.length] = "Lemon";  // Adds "Lemon" to fruits

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
fruits[fruits.length] = "Lemon";  // Adds "Lemon" to fruits

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
fruits[fruits.length] = "Lemon";  // Adds "Lemon" to fruits

content.text: WARNING !
content.html: WARNING !

content.text: Adding elements with high indexes can create undefined "holes" in an array:
content.html: Adding elements with high indexes can create undefined "holes" in an array:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
fruits[6] = "Lemon";  // Creates undefined "holes" in fruits

content.code:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
fruits[6] = "Lemon";  // Creates undefined "holes" in fruits

syntax_highlighting.text:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
fruits[6] = "Lemon";  // Creates undefined "holes" in fruits

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
fruits[6] = "Lemon";  // Creates undefined "holes" in fruits

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
fruits[6] = "Lemon";  // Creates undefined "holes" in fruits

content.text: Associative Arrays
Many programming languages support arrays with named indexes.
content.html: Many programming languages support arrays with named indexes.

content.text: Arrays with named indexes are called associative arrays (or hashes).
content.html: Arrays with named indexes are called associative arrays (or hashes).

content.text: JavaScript does not support arrays with named indexes.
content.html: JavaScript does not support arrays with named indexes.

content.text: In JavaScript, arrays always use numbered indexes .
content.html: In JavaScript, arrays always use numbered indexes.

content.code_html:
const person = [];
person[0] = "John";
person[1] = "Doe";
person[2] = 46;
person.length;    // Will return 3
 person[0];        // Will return "John"

content.text: WARNING !! If you use named indexes, JavaScript will redefine the array to an object.
content.html:
WARNING !!
If you use named indexes, JavaScript will redefine the array to an object.

content.text: After that, some array methods and properties will produce incorrect results .
content.html: After that, some array methods and properties will produce incorrect results.

content.code_html:
const person = [];
person["firstName"] = "John";
person["lastName"] = "Doe";
person["age"] = 46;
person.length;     // Will return 0
 person[0];         // Will return undefined

content.text: The Difference Between Arrays and Objects
In JavaScript, arrays use numbered indexes .
content.html: In JavaScript, arrays use numbered indexes.

content.text: In JavaScript, objects use named indexes .
content.html: In JavaScript, objects use named indexes.

content.text: Arrays are a special kind of objects, with numbered indexes.
content.html: Arrays are a special kind of objects, with numbered indexes.

content.text: When to Use Arrays. When to use Objects.
JavaScript new Array()
JavaScript has a built-in array constructor new Array() .
content.html: JavaScript has a built-in array constructor new Array().

content.text: But you can safely use [] instead.
content.html: But you can safely use [] instead.

content.text: These two different statements both create a new empty array named points:
content.html: These two different statements both create a new empty array named points:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const points = new Array();
const points = [];

content.code:
const points = new Array();
const points = [];

syntax_highlighting.text:
const points = new Array();
const points = [];

content.code_html:
const points = new Array();
const points = [];

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const points = new Array();
const points = [];

content.text: These two different statements both create a new array containing 6 numbers:
content.html: These two different statements both create a new array containing 6 numbers:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const points = new Array(40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10);
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];

content.code:
const points = new Array(40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10);
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];

const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];

const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const points = new Array(40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10);
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];

content.text: How to Recognize an Array
A common question is: How do I know if a variable is an array?
content.html: A common question is: How do I know if a variable is an array?

content.text: The problem is that the JavaScript operator typeof returns " object ":
content.html: The problem is that the JavaScript operator typeof returns "object":

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
let type = typeof fruits;

content.code:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
let type = typeof fruits;

syntax_highlighting.text:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
let type = typeof fruits;

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
let type = typeof fruits;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
let type = typeof fruits;

content.text: The typeof operator returns object because a JavaScript array is an object.
content.html: The typeof operator returns object because a JavaScript array is an object.

content.text: Solution 1:
To solve this problem ECMAScript 5 (JavaScript 2009) defined a new method Array.isArray() :
content.html: To solve this problem ECMAScript 5 (JavaScript 2009) defined a new method Array.isArray():

content.code: Array.isArray(fruits);
content.code_html: Array.isArray(fruits);

content.text: Solution 2:
The instanceof operator returns true if an object is created by a given constructor:
content.html: The instanceof operator returns true if an object is created by a given constructor:

content.code:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];
(fruits instanceof Array);
content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple"];

(fruits instanceof Array);

content.text: Nested Arrays and Objects
Values in objects can be arrays, and values in arrays can be objects:
content.html: Values in objects can be arrays, and values in arrays can be objects:

content.code_html:
const myObj = {
  name: "John",
  age: 30,
  cars: [
    {name:"Ford", models:["Fiesta", "Focus", "Mustang"]},
    {name:"BMW", models:["320", "X3", "X5"]},
    {name:"Fiat", models:["500", "Panda"]}
  ]
}

content.text: To access arrays inside arrays, use a for-in loop for each array:
content.html: To access arrays inside arrays, use a for-in loop for each array:

content.code_html:
for (let i in myObj.cars) {
  x += "<h1>" + myObj.cars[i].name + "</h1>";
  for (let j in myObj.cars[i].models) {
    x += myObj.cars[i].models[j];
  }
}
